trans-unit.source: Displays a hyperlink-style button control on a Web page.

In this topic: - [Introduction](#introduction) - [LinkButton Controls and Validation](#ButtonControlsAndValidation) - [Declarative Syntax](#DeclarativeSyntax) ## Introduction Use the LinkButton control to create a hyperlink-style button on the Web page.
The LinkButton control has the same appearance as a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.HyperLink> control, but has the same functionality as a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Button> control.
If you want to link to another Web page when the control is clicked, consider using the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.HyperLink> control.
> [!NOTE] > The LinkButton control renders JavaScript to the client browser.
The client browser must have JavaScript enabled for this control to function properly.
For more information on client script, see [Client Script in ASP.NET Web Pages](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
You can create either a Submit button or a Command button.
A Submit button does not have a command name associated with it.
The button simply posts the Web page back to the server.
By default, a LinkButton control is a Submit button.
You can provide an event handler for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.Click> event to programmatically control the actions performed when the Submit button is clicked.
On the other hand, a Command button has a command name associated with the button, such as `Sort`.
Set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.CommandName%2A> property to specify the command name.
This allows you to create multiple LinkButton controls on a Web page and programmatically determine which LinkButton control is clicked.

You can also use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.CommandArgument%2A> property with a Command button to provide additional information about the command to perform, such as specifying ascending order.
You can also provide an event handler for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.Command> event to programmatically control the action performed when the Command button is clicked.
> [!CAUTION] > This control can be used to display user input, which might include malicious client script.
Text is not HTML encoded before it is displayed in the LinkButton control.
Check any information that is sent from a client for executable script, SQL statements, or other code before displaying it in your application.
ASP.NET provides an input request validation feature to block script and HTML in user input.
Validation server controls are also provided to assess user input.
For more information, see [Validation Server Control Syntax](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/96d2c59e-693c-4079-9b53-b3ff0d9e9133).
## LinkButton Controls and Validation By default, page validation is performed when a LinkButton control is clicked.
Page validation determines whether the input controls associated with a validation control on the page all pass the validation rules specified by the validation control.
To prevent page validation from occurring, set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.CausesValidation%2A> property to `false`.
## Declarative Syntax ``` ```
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> class.
Use this constructor to create and initialize a new instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control.
Adds the attributes of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control to the output stream for rendering on the client.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter"></xref> that contains the output stream to render on the client.
Notifies the control that an element, either XML or HTML, was parsed, and adds the element to the control's <xref href="System.Web.UI.ControlCollection"></xref> object.
An <xref:System.Object> that represents the parsed element.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether validation is performed when the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control is clicked.
By default, page validation is performed when a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control is clicked.
Page validation determines whether the input controls associated with a validation control on the page all pass the validation rules specified by the validation control.

You can specify (or determine) whether validation is performed on both the client and the server when a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control is clicked by using the CausesValidation property.
To prevent validation from being performed, set the CausesValidation property to `false`.
This property is commonly set to `false` for a Reset or Clear button to prevent validation from being performed when the button is clicked.

When the value of the CausesValidation property is set to `true`, you can also use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.ValidationGroup%2A> property to specify the name of the validation group for which the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control causes validation.
This property cannot be set by themes or style sheet themes.
For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> and [ASP.NET Themes and Skins](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if validation is performed when the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control is clicked; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
The default value is <xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref>.
Occurs when the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control is clicked.
The Click event is raised when the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control is clicked.
This event is commonly used when no command name is associated with the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control, as in the case of a Submit button.
For more information about handling events, see [NIB: Consuming Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/01e4f1bc-e55e-413f-98c7-6588493e5f67).
To be added.
Occurs when the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control is clicked.
The Command event is raised when the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control is clicked.
This event is commonly used when a command name, such as `Sort`, is associated with the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control.

This allows you to create multiple <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> controls on a Web page and programmatically determine which <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control is clicked.
> [!NOTE] > The Command event is raised through the control hierarchy in the form of the `BubbleEvent`.
For more information about handling events, see [NIB: Consuming Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/01e4f1bc-e55e-413f-98c7-6588493e5f67).
To be added.

Gets or sets an optional argument passed to the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.Command"></xref> event handler along with the associated <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.CommandName*> property.
Use the CommandArgument property to specify an argument that complements the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.CommandName%2A> property.
> [!NOTE] > The CommandArgument property is typically only used when the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.CommandName%2A> property is set.
The CommandArgument property complements the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.CommandName%2A> property by allowing you to provide any additional information about the command to perform.

For example, you can set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.CommandName%2A> property to `Sort` and set the CommandArgument property to `Ascending` to specify a command to sort in ascending order.
This property cannot be set by themes or style sheet themes.
For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> and [ASP.NET Themes and Skins](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).

An optional argument passed to the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.Command"></xref> event handler along with the associated <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.CommandName*> property.
The default value is <xref:System.String.Empty?displayProperty=fullName>.
Gets or sets the command name associated with the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control.
This value is passed to the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.Command"></xref> event handler along with the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.CommandArgument*> property.

When you have multiple <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> controls on a Web page, use the CommandName property to specify or determine the command name associated with the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control clicked.
You can set the CommandName property with any string that identifies the command to perform.
You can then programmatically determine the command name of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control and perform the appropriate actions.
Additional information about the command, such as an `Ascending` sort order, can be specified by using the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.CommandArgument%2A> property.
This property cannot be set by themes or style sheet themes.
For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> and [ASP.NET Themes and Skins](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
The command name of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control.
The default value is <xref:System.String.Empty?displayProperty=fullName>.
Creates a <xref href="System.Web.UI.PostBackOptions"></xref> object that represents the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control's postback behavior.
The GetPostBackOptions method creates a <xref:System.Web.UI.PostBackOptions> object that represents the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control's postback behavior.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.PostBackOptions> object is then typically passed to the <xref:System.Web.UI.ClientScriptManager.GetPostBackEventReference%28System.Web.UI.PostBackOptions%29?displayProperty=fullName> method, which is used to obtain a reference to a client-side script function that, when invoked, causes the server to post back to the page.
This method is used primarily by control developers when extending the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> class.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.PostBackOptions"></xref> that represents the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control's postback behavior.
Restores view-state information from a previous request that was saved with the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.SaveViewState*> method.
An object that represents the control state to restore.
Raises the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.Click"></xref> event of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.Click> event is raised when the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control is clicked.
This event is commonly used when no command name is associated with the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control, as in the case of a Submit button.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [NIB: Raising an Event](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/f2adaf01-1ed1-42e1-8c31-8d467e7e0ee2).
The OnClick method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
A <xref:System.EventArgs?displayProperty=fullName> that contains the event data.

Gets or sets the client-side script that executes when a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control's <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.Click"></xref> event is raised

Use the OnClientClick property to specify additional client-side script that executes when the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control's <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.Click> event is raised.
The script that you specify for this property is rendered in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control's `OnClick` attribute in addition to the control's predefined client-side script.
This property cannot be set by themes or style sheet themes.
For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> and [ASP.NET Themes and Skins](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
The client-side script that executes when a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control's <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.Click"></xref> event is raised.
Raises the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.Command"></xref> event of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.Command> event is raised when the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control is clicked.
This event is commonly used when a command name, such as `Sort`, is associated with the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control.

This allows you to create multiple <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> controls on a Web page and programmatically determine which <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control is clicked.
> [!NOTE] > The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.Command> event is raised through the control hierarchy in the form of the `BubbleEvent`.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [NIB: Raising an Event](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/f2adaf01-1ed1-42e1-8c31-8d467e7e0ee2).
The OnCommand method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.CommandEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.PreRender"></xref> event.
The OnPreRender method notifies the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control to perform any necessary prerendering steps prior to saving view state and rendering content to the client.
An <xref:System.EventArgs> object that contains the event data.
Gets or sets the URL of the page to post to from the current page when the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control is clicked.
The PostBackUrl property allows you to perform a cross-page post using the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control.
Set the PostBackUrl property to the URL of the Web page to post to when the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control is clicked.
For example, specifying Page2.aspx causes the page that contains the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control to post to `Page2.aspx`.
If you do not specify a value for the PostBackUrl property, the page posts back to itself.

> [!IMPORTANT] > When performing a cross-page postback with controls with server-side validation, you should check that the page's <xref:System.Web.UI.Page.IsValid%2A> property is `true` before processing the postback.
In the case of a cross-page postback, the page to check is the PreviousPage.

The following Visual Basic code shows how this is done: ``` Sub Page_Load(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As System.EventArgs) Handles Me.Load If Page.PreviousPage.IsValid Then ' Handle the post back Else Response.Write("Invalid") End If End Sub ``` For more information on cross-page posting techniques, see [Cross-Page Posting in ASP.NET Web Forms](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
This property cannot be set by themes or style sheet themes.
For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> and [ASP.NET Themes and Skins](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
The URL of the Web page to post to from the current page when the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control is clicked.
The default value is an empty string (""), which causes the page to post back to itself.
Raises events for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control when it posts back to the server.

This event is used internally by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control, when it is clicked, to raise a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.Click> event, and if defined, a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.Command> event.
The argument for the event.
Renders the contents of the control to the specified writer.
This method is used primarily by control developers.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter"></xref> that represents the output stream to render HTML content on the client.

Gets a value that indicates whether the control should set the <xref uid="langword_csharp_disabled" name="disabled" href=""></xref> attribute of the rendered HTML element to "disabled" when the control's <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.IsEnabled*> property is <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
This property indicates how ASP.NET should render HTML for a control when the control is disabled.
If this property is `true`, ASP.NET renders a `disabled` attribute when a control is disabled.
If this property is `false`, ASP.NET renders a `class` attribute when a control is disabled.
For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.SupportsDisabledAttribute%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.RenderingCompatibility%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property indicates an ASP.NET version lower than `4.0`; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
For a description of this member, see <xref:System.Web.UI.IPostBackEventHandler.RaisePostBackEvent%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.
This member is an explicit interface member implementation.
It can be used only when the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> instance is cast to an <xref:System.Web.UI.IPostBackEventHandler> interface.
The argument for the event.
Gets or sets the text caption displayed on the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control.
Use the Text property to specify or determine the caption to display on the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control.
> [!CAUTION] > This control can be used to display user input, which might include malicious client script.
Check any information that is sent from a client for executable script, SQL statements, or other code before displaying it in your application.
ASP.NET provides an input request validation feature to block script and HTML in user input.
Validation server controls are also provided to assess user input.
For more information, see [Validation Server Control Syntax](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/96d2c59e-693c-4079-9b53-b3ff0d9e9133).
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool.
For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
The text caption displayed on the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control.
The default value is an empty string ("").
Gets or sets the group of controls for which the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control causes validation when it posts back to the server.
Validation groups allow you to assign validation controls on a page to a specific category.
Each validation group can be validated independently of other validation groups on the page.
Use the ValidationGroup property to specify the name of the validation group for which the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control causes validation when it posts back to the server.
This property has an effect only when the value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.CausesValidation%2A> property is set to `true`.

When you specify a value for the ValidationGroup property, only the validation controls that are part of the specified group are validated when the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton> control posts back to the server.

If you do not specify a value for this property and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton.CausesValidation%2A> property is set to `true`, all validation controls on the page that are not assigned to a validation group are validated when the control posts back to the server.
This property cannot be set by themes or style sheet themes.
For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> and [ASP.NET Themes and Skins](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
The group of controls for which the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton"></xref> control causes validation when it posts back to the server.
The default value is an empty string ("").
